By KENNETH ZIERLER
This is a tribute to Dr. William
Kelso Morrill. The final score Saturday was 10 to 9 against his team
In an overtime contest, but for the
present we shall consider the final
score as incidental to something bigger. Kels won't like that. Saturday
afternoon he didn't think there was
anything bigger than winning that
lacrosse game against St. John's.
For three quartres St. John's didn't
belong on the same field with Hopkins. After only a few minutes of
play, Bob Levi passed from behind
the goal to Jack Kaufman for the
first tally. About midway in the initial period, Levi fed Charley Orth,
who promptly placed the ball in the
goal on a neat shot from a bad angle.
Hopkins Teamwork
The Blue team was a team. The
ten men played as unit. The attack
worked the ball in for shots from the
hole. The defense switched with machine-like precision to completely silence the block plays of the Johnny
1-0g. guns. The several shots that were
taken by the Crabtowners were handled by goalie Lou Reuling. And
then Lou got hurt—a bad leg injury
that took him out of the game and
will probably keep him out of the
Maryland game. Cliff Gilbert—as fine
a goalkeeper as Reuling—went in to
hold St. John's scoreless the rest of

Cartoonists Wanted
At 'News-Letter' Office
As Soon As Possible
Will anyone who can draw and
who would be interested in cartooning please report to the NEWSLETTER office at 12.30 as soon as
possible?
We are anxious to have someone
who is able to draw cartoons of
campus figures, activities, and policies; and any one wishing to try
his ability will be welcomed.
There is a good opportunity for
gaining experience in this field;
so if you think you possess even
an artistic ability, come down to
the office and let us know, or get
in touch with Jesse Borden, Box
41.

The Johns Hopkins Hospital sustaining fund drive has reached the
total of $234,134, it was announced
last week by W. Frank Roberts, the
chairman of the committee attempting to raise the money. The original
goal set by the committee was $200,000.
The final luncheon held last Friday
was addressed by Dr. Simon Flexner,
director of the Rockefeller Institute,
who said that the "spirit of the great
four was being carried on with diminution." He referred to Drs. Howard
Kelly, Sir William Osier, William H.
Welch, and William S. Halstead as
the "Great Four."

The Johns Hopkins track squad
sent eight men to the Middle Atlantics
last week-end and qualified six places,
but could score only five points in
the finals.
Captain Willard Neu and Paul
Holtzman were the two Jay competitors who came through to tally when
all the other Black and Blue runners
were shut out. Neu secured second
in the broad-jump, while Holtzman
received fifth in the two-male grind.
In the former event, the Blue Jay
representative was just beaten out
by one jump, which was achieved in
the preliminary rounds on Friday. It
is possible that Neu might have topped this mark the following day, but
after three leaps he was forced to
withdraw because of a sprained muscle. His distance, however, was enough

The principal speaker will be Lawrence B. Fenneman, prominent Baltimore attorney, who was president
of the chapter when it was first organized in 1922. He also headed the
fraternity in his senior year, 1922-23.
Mr. Fenneman was managing editor
of the former Black and Blue Jay in
his junior year and editor-in-chief of
The Hullabaloo in 1923. What the
speaker's subject will be was not
known at late as today.
Luncheon To Follow
Hyman M. Levin, who headed the
Hopkins chapter of Pi Delta Epsilon
in 1933-34 and who now holds the
position of assistant to the national
national officers of the organization,
will be another speaker at the public
initiation. Following an introduction
by Robert A. McKericher, president
of the chapter now, Levin will discuss
briefly the place of a journalism fraternity on a college campus.
Following the assembly, a luncheon
will be held in Levering Hal in honor
of the new members and the guest
speakers.Others who wil attend the
luncheon are Dr. E. Wilbur Berry,
dean, who is an honorary member of
the fraternity, and Dr. John C.
French, head librarian and active in
journalistice activities in his Hopkins undergraduate days.

Class B Listed
The Class B outboard motor boats

Class race, which is scheduled to begin at 3.45 p. m.
The Stock Runabouts Class race,
which will begin at 4.10 p. m., promises to be one of the most exciting
races on the program The event calls
for four laps around the course, a
distance of 10 miles.
T. Rogers Bartlett is general chairman of the Racing Committee, Dr.
Cecil Bagley is the advisory chairman, and Paul Holtzman is the racing chairman.
Racing Committee Named
The Racing Committee includes Dr.
Bagley, Bartlett, William Bourne,
Alan Hill, Holtzman, William Ponder,
Edward Rainey, Charles P. Reckner
and William Roche. The Information
Committee has Burton G. Cannon,
William Follmer, Hamilton O'Dunne
and Roland Merson as its members.
Awards will be presented to the first
three boats finishing in the five classes. Several leading citizens, including
Mayor Howard W. Jackson, have
placed cups and other prizes incompetition for the winning boats. It is
the second consecutive year that
Mayor Jackson has placed a cup in
competition.
Blanks Now Available
Entrance blanks are available from
T. Rogers Bartlett or may be secured
from Paul Holtzman at P. 0. Box
558 at the University. Entrants for
the five races will have no entrance
fees to pay, it was announced by the

committee.

Letter From
A Materialist
A Program Of Hope For
The Mentarian Kingdom
By SIDNEY H. LEVY
Mr. Edgar Kemler, the Great Mentarian and comrade of Voltaire, Erasmus, Cervantes, and Shaw, has presumably submerged his "human" ego
in an "anti-human" discernment of
the "cold

facts

of

the

universe"

which, despite the "awful opposition
of his spontaneous emotions," he has
now proceeded to read into life. What
a truly remarkable achievement! But
it is really unfortunate that the Mentarian ego has been thus submerged.
Else how it would revel in this glorious triumph of the pure intellect over
the base animal passions of the amoeba, the dog, and Huey Long!
The essence of the Mentarian Manifesto—stripped of the glittering sophistries of Kemlerian verbosity—seems
to be that the Mentarian is a man,
but a new breed of man, and as such
quite distinct from the rest of the
species. But even Mr. Kemler will
certainly admit that the great intellects of all time have had to concern
themselves about the vulgar necessities of mere animal existence before ascending to the chilly stratosphere in which the pure intellect holds
sway. Thus they are essentially the
same as men. AND LIKE ALL MEN
THE FUNCTIONING OF THEIR
INTELLECT IS CONDITIONED BY
THE MATERIAL ENVIRONMENT

We Congratulate

IN WHICH THEY OPERATE. TRY
AS THEY WILL THEY CANNOT

The Barnstormers

Having traveled the "Road to
Rome," we return singing the praises
of those who made the trip so pleasant. From the viewpoint of the observer in the audience the play was
completely successful. The cast gave
an excellent performance which we
think excelled that of the other production which the Barnstomers presented this past season.
Lifting the curtain for a moment,
we wish to bring into the spotlight
Messrs. William B. Banks and Howard M. 'Caplan, who produced the
play, and Allan Delevett and Frank
Mirschman, who headed the business
and production staffs, respectively.
These men are to be congratulated
for their fine work which, although it
doesn't occupy the center of the stage,
is responsible in great measure for the
success of the play.
Again we wish to urge the Barnstormers to continue the custom of
presenting at least two productions a
season. If the club continues to give
good plays we are certain that the
students will support them. Surely
with the abundance of talent—in the
acting, production, and business staffs
—which we saw Saturday night, the
'Stormers should have no trouble
whatsoever in making a more frequent appearance on the stage.

The June Week
Committee
The June Week Committee has announced that it has been able to arrange a Varsity Alumni lacrosse game
as part of the festivities scheduled for
,the graduating Seniors. The committee has done its job competently and
has planned an extensive, fine entertainment. The acquisition of the services of Ray Noble's and Hal Kemp's
orchestras for the Junior and Senior
Balls, respectively, will lend a true
festive touch to the activities of the
week.
June Week will be a real send-off
to the Seniors.

Jane Tinsley Wins
Award
The Playshop of the Johns Hopkins
University announces the award of the
Pearl Head Latcham prize for the
best original one-act play produced at
the Playshop during the season just
concluded to Miss Jane Tinsley. Miss
Tinsley is a student in playwriting in
the College for Teachers of the Johns
Her playlet,
Hopkins University.
"Two Women Meet," is the first play
she has ever written.
The judges
were: Mrs. Diana Rogge, local playwright and member of the Vagabonds; Mr. David N. Finck, director
of the Jewish Dramatic Guild; and
Mrs. Leola Myers, a leading member
of the Playshop organization.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 14, 1935.

-:- 01' Bill Comes To Life -:By JACK STEIN
Through the three hundred and
thirty-five years which have elapsed
since old Bill Shakespeare wrote his
trio of comedies involving three unfemales—Beatrice, in
forgettable
Much Ado About Nothing; Rosalind,
in As You Like „It, and Viola in
Twelfth Night—we have suffered interminable anguish having to put up
with such rank amateurs as Hemingway, Coward and other so-called
"modern" playwrights.
An oasis was discovered by your
reviewer last Thursday night when he
attended the opening performance of
Shakespeare's immortal—and immoral—comedy, Much Ado About Nothing.
Director Paul Hinrichs, with that
rare insight which causes him to be
ranked among Baltimore's leading authorities on play producing, chose the
Guild Theatre for his production, because as he says "'The intimacy and
complete lack of formality in and
about the Guild aids materially in
producing the Shakespearean atmosphere which is so necessary for the
complete enjoyment of Much Ado.
The story of Much Ado in brief,
confirmed
Benedick, a
concerns
bachelor; Claudio, a handsome young
lord; and Hero and Beatrice, two
charming young ladies. By various
clever means Benedick, the "bachelor," becomes Bendeick, the "marrie man," and Claudio finds a lovely wife in Hero, but not until after—
well, why say?
The leading roles of Bendeick and
Beatrice are handled by Williaw Oberle and Hilary Sash, respectively.
Two experienced actors, they carried
their parts with a polish and precision which denotes that they are accomplished thespians.
The role of Hero was taken by the
"Sweeatheart of Hopkins", Miss Alice
Clautice. Miss Clautice takes this
part, and figuratively speaking,
"knocks it for a loop." There is little doubt that within the next few
years with a little more experience,
Miss Clautice can look forward to
success on a Broadway stages. Her
excellent emotional ability is demonstrated vividly during the scene in
which Hero learns of derogatory remarks concerning he chastity. She
changes from a sweet blushing bride
to a horror stricken individual with
such convincing realism that had old
Bill Shake seen Miss Clautice. in the
part of Hero, he would have undoubtedly changed the lines so as to lessen
the shock brought about by gullible
Claudio.
Director Hinrichs is one of the few
Baltimore directors who can handle
a role capably and at the same time
direct a play. Mr. Hinrichs appeared
on the stage in the role of Don Pedro. He acted his part with great finesse, giving evidence of his many
years of stage experience.
Mr. A. H. Young-O'Brien, in his

role of Dogberry, very humorously
played the part of the village constable.
Alexander Boas, as the handsome
suitor for the hand of Hero, will, I
think with a few more performances,
carry his part in a more definite way.
At present he seems a little shaky.
This may be accounted for when it is
taken into consideration that Mr.
Boas is making his first attempt at
Shakespeare.
Mr. Carl Barron, well-known Playmaster and experienced Shakespearean actor, handles his role as "villain" with a silky smoothness. Mr.
Jones played the part of Antonio, in
Twelfth Night„ and was also seen in
She Stoops to Conquer, by Olivet
Goldsmith.
An excellent performance was rendered by Charles Perry in the role of
Leonata, father of Hero. Others in
the cast are John Noon, Constance
Carroll, John McDivett and Warren
Jones.
The Playmasters, producers of this
play, were organized in the early
part of 1934. Their aim is to produce "plays by masters" in a modern
up-to-date manner. Thus far this season their plays have been "Twelfth
Night," "She Stoops to Conquer,"
"Cargo From Rhodes," and "Much
Ado About Nothing."
"Twelfth Night," in response to
popular demand, will return to the
Guild Theatre with an opening performance tonight. Special price student tickets for both "Much Ado" and
"Twelfth Night" can be obtained at
the reserve desk in the main reading
room of the library.

SYNTHETIC SUNLIGHT
HE people whose apartments faced the
lower levels of the ventilating shafts in a
14-story New York apartment house had long
ago given up the hope that direct sunlight
would enter their windows. Imagine their
astonishment one morning not long ago to find
light —lots of it — streaming in. When they
looked, they found not the sun, but 18 of the
sun's able little imitators—General Electric
floodlights. They had been mounted on the
ninth-floor level.
The engineers were thoughtful of the tenants'
feelings. For when the switch is thrown no
sudden glare of light paralyzes unaccustomed
householders in the act of brushing their teeth
or doing setting up exercises, pastimes which
were formerly cloaked in intimate gloom. A
fully automatic synchronous-motor time switch
actuates a dimmer, and the floodlights do not
attain full brilliancy for 15 minutes.

Because of weight and clearance requirements,
however, the route of the shipment was round
about. A check of practically every foot of the
way was made to determine if temporary obstructions could be removed to allow the load
to pass. From Schenectady to Wilkes-Barre,
Pa., the car traveled on the Delaware & Hudson. From Wilkes-Barre, the ear was sent to
Hagerstown, Md., on the Pennsylvania Railroad, where it was turned over to the Western
Maryland Railroad. After an extensive detour,
it was delivered back to the Pennsylvania on
its main line just south of the Baltimore
tunnels, which were the principal reasons for
the complicated routing. From there it was
carried directly to the power company's siding
in the District of Columbia.

under what is believed to be the heaviest load
ever transported on a single car. The load consisted of the generator shaft, rotor, and poles

Electric Light and Power Company to deliver

FISH LIFE SAVER
THE people in the New York Aquarium
were very unhappy. Many of their rare
fish were dying of a mysterious malady. An
investigation showed that the water pumped
into the tanks contained contaminating metal
salts, and that these salts came from the metal
pumps in the system.
They appealed to the H. A. Smith Pump &
Motor Company for help. Mr. Smith began
testing all the nonmetallic substances available
for making pumps. He tried 14 materials and
found that General Electric Textolite was the
only one that would prevent this pollution of
the water and at the same time make a satisfactory pump.
Engineers of the General Electric Plastics
Department were called in, and a new pump
was designed, using five different grades of
Textolite. The pump was so constructed that
no water can come into contact with metal.

national officers of the organization,

A Materialist
A Program Of Hope For
The Mentarian Kingdom
By SIDNEY H. LEVY
Mr. Edgar Kemler, the Great Mentarian and comrade of Voltaire, Erasmus, Cervantes, and Shaw, has presumably submerged his "human" ego
in an "anti-human" discernment of
the "cold

facts

of

the

universe"

which, despite the "awful opposition
of his spontaneous emotions," he has
now proceeded to read into life. What
a truly remarkable achievement! But
it is really unfortunate that the Mentarian ego has been thus submerged.
Else how it would revel in this glorious triumph of the pure intellect over
the base animal passions of the amoeba, the dog, and Huey Long!
The essence of the Mentarian Manifesto—stripped of the glittering sophistries of Kemlerian verbosity—seems
to be that the Mentarian is a man,
but a new breed of man, and as such
quite distinct from the rest of the
species. But even Mr. Kemler will
certainly admit that the great intellects of all time have had to concern
themselves about the vulgar necessities of mere animal existence before ascending to the chilly stratosphere in which the pure intellect holds
sway. Thus they are essentially the
same as men. AND LIKE ALL MEN
THE FUNCTIONING OF THEIR
INTELLECT IS CONDITIONED BY
THE MATERIAL ENVIRONMENT

The Barnstormers

CIETY OF MEN. TO ATTEMPT TO

Having traveled the "Road to
Rome," we return singing the praises
of those who made the trip so pleasant. From the viewpoint of the observer in the audience the play was
completely successful. The cast gave
an excellent performance which we
think excelled that of the other production which the Barnstomers presented this past season.
Lifting the curtain for a moment,
we wish to bring into the spotlight
Messrs. William B. Banks and Howard M. 'Caplan, who produced the
play, and Allan Delevett and Frank
Mirschman, who headed the business
and production staffs, respectively.
These men are to be congratulated
for their fine work which, although it
doesn't occupy the center of the stage,
is responsible in great measure for the
success of the play.
Again we wish to urge the Barnstormers to continue the custom of
presenting at least two productions a
season. If the club continues to give
good plays we are certain that the
students will support them. Surely
with the abundance of talent—in the
acting, production, and business staffs
—which we saw Saturday night, the
'Stormers should have no trouble
whatsoever in making a more frequent appearance on the stage.

The June Week
Committee
The June Week Committee has announced that it has been able to arrange a Varsity Alumni lacrosse game
as part of the festivities scheduled for
,the graduating Seniors. The committee has done its job competently and
has planned an extensive, fine entertainment. The acquisition of the services of Ray Noble's and Hal Kemp's
orchestras for the Junior and Senior
Balls, respectively, will lend a true
festive touch to the activities of the
week.
June Week will be a real send-off
to the Seniors.

Jane Tinsley Wins
Award
The Playshop of the Johns Hopkins
University announces the award of the
Pearl Head Latcham prize for the
best original one-act play produced at
the Playshop during the season just
concluded to Miss Jane Tinsley. Miss
Tinsley is a student in playwriting in
the College for Teachers of the Johns
Her playlet,
Hopkins University.
"Two Women Meet," is the first play
she has ever written.
The judges
were: Mrs. Diana Rogge, local playwright and member of the Vagabonds; Mr. David N. Finck, director
of the Jewish Dramatic Guild; and
Mrs. Leola Myers, a leading member
of the Playshop organization.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 14, 1935.

-:- 01' Bill Comes To Life -:By JACK STEIN
Through the three hundred and
thirty-five years which have elapsed
since old Bill Shakespeare wrote his
trio of comedies involving three unfemales—Beatrice, in
forgettable
Much Ado About Nothing; Rosalind,
in As You Like „It, and Viola in
Twelfth Night—we have suffered interminable anguish having to put up
with such rank amateurs as Hemingway, Coward and other so-called
"modern" playwrights.
An oasis was discovered by your
reviewer last Thursday night when he
attended the opening performance of
Shakespeare's immortal—and immoral—comedy, Much Ado About Nothing.
Director Paul Hinrichs, with that
rare insight which causes him to be
ranked among Baltimore's leading authorities on play producing, chose the
Guild Theatre for his production, because as he says "'The intimacy and
complete lack of formality in and
about the Guild aids materially in
producing the Shakespearean atmosphere which is so necessary for the
complete enjoyment of Much Ado.
The story of Much Ado in brief,
confirmed
Benedick, a
concerns
bachelor; Claudio, a handsome young
lord; and Hero and Beatrice, two
charming young ladies. By various
clever means Benedick, the "bachelor," becomes Bendeick, the "marrie man," and Claudio finds a lovely wife in Hero, but not until after—
well, why say?
The leading roles of Bendeick and
Beatrice are handled by Williaw Oberle and Hilary Sash, respectively.
Two experienced actors, they carried
their parts with a polish and precision which denotes that they are accomplished thespians.
The role of Hero was taken by the
"Sweeatheart of Hopkins", Miss Alice
Clautice. Miss Clautice takes this
part, and figuratively speaking,
"knocks it for a loop." There is little doubt that within the next few
years with a little more experience,
Miss Clautice can look forward to
success on a Broadway stages. Her
excellent emotional ability is demonstrated vividly during the scene in
which Hero learns of derogatory remarks concerning he chastity. She
changes from a sweet blushing bride
to a horror stricken individual with
such convincing realism that had old
Bill Shake seen Miss Clautice. in the
part of Hero, he would have undoubtedly changed the lines so as to lessen
the shock brought about by gullible
Claudio.
Director Hinrichs is one of the few
Baltimore directors who can handle
a role capably and at the same time
direct a play. Mr. Hinrichs appeared
on the stage in the role of Don Pedro. He acted his part with great finesse, giving evidence of his many
years of stage experience.
Mr. A. H. Young-O'Brien, in his

role of Dogberry, very humorously
played the part of the village constable.
Alexander Boas, as the handsome
suitor for the hand of Hero, will, I
think with a few more performances,
carry his part in a more definite way.
At present he seems a little shaky.
This may be accounted for when it is
taken into consideration that Mr.
Boas is making his first attempt at
Shakespeare.
Mr. Carl Barron, well-known Playmaster and experienced Shakespearean actor, handles his role as "villain" with a silky smoothness. Mr.
Jones played the part of Antonio, in
Twelfth Night„ and was also seen in
She Stoops to Conquer, by Olivet
Goldsmith.
An excellent performance was rendered by Charles Perry in the role of
Leonata, father of Hero. Others in
the cast are John Noon, Constance
Carroll, John McDivett and Warren
Jones.
The Playmasters, producers of this
play, were organized in the early
part of 1934. Their aim is to produce "plays by masters" in a modern
up-to-date manner. Thus far this season their plays have been "Twelfth
Night," "She Stoops to Conquer,"
"Cargo From Rhodes," and "Much
Ado About Nothing."
"Twelfth Night," in response to
popular demand, will return to the
Guild Theatre with an opening performance tonight. Special price student tickets for both "Much Ado" and
"Twelfth Night" can be obtained at
the reserve desk in the main reading
room of the library.

SYNTHETIC SUNLIGHT
HE people whose apartments faced the
lower levels of the ventilating shafts in a
14-story New York apartment house had long
ago given up the hope that direct sunlight
would enter their windows. Imagine their
astonishment one morning not long ago to find
light —lots of it — streaming in. When they
looked, they found not the sun, but 18 of the
sun's able little imitators—General Electric
floodlights. They had been mounted on the
ninth-floor level.
The engineers were thoughtful of the tenants'
feelings. For when the switch is thrown no
sudden glare of light paralyzes unaccustomed
householders in the act of brushing their teeth
or doing setting up exercises, pastimes which
were formerly cloaked in intimate gloom. A
fully automatic synchronous-motor time switch
actuates a dimmer, and the floodlights do not
attain full brilliancy for 15 minutes.

however, the route of the shipment was round
about. A check of practically every foot of the
way was made to determine if temporary obstructions could be removed to allow the load
to pass. From Schenectady to Wilkes-Barre,
Pa., the car traveled on the Delaware & Hudson. From Wilkes-Barre, the ear was sent to
Hagerstown, Md., on the Pennsylvania Railroad, where it was turned over to the Western
Maryland Railroad. After an extensive detour,
it was delivered back to the Pennsylvania on
its main line just south of the Baltimore
tunnels, which were the principal reasons for
the complicated routing. From there it was
carried directly to the power company's siding
in the District of Columbia.

FISH LIFE SAVER
THE people in the New York Aquarium
were very unhappy. Many of their rare
fish were dying of a mysterious malady. An
investigation showed that the water pumped
into the tanks contained contaminating metal
salts, and that these salts came from the metal
pumps in the system.
They appealed to the H. A. Smith Pump &
Motor Company for help. Mr. Smith began
testing all the nonmetallic substances available
for making pumps. He tried 14 materials and
found that General Electric Textolite was the
only one that would prevent this pollution of
the water and at the same time make a satisfactory pump.
Engineers of the General Electric Plastics
Department were called in, and a new pump
was designed, using five different grades of
Textolite. The pump was so constructed that
no water can come into contact with metal.

Rally In Ninth
Hopkins started a rally in the last
inning but were stopped after they
had scored two runs. Thus the final
score stood 18 to 13 in favor of Haverford.
In spite of the Hopkins defeat, the
game was satisfying in that it showed
that the team has strength behind
the bat. Also, their was a noticeable
improvement in fielding, and the Jays
were credited with few errors.
Especially outstanding for Hopkins
was Stevens who turned in a creditable performance both in batting and
fielding.
